body: What libuv version are you using? Please use latest code from the v1.x branch, this should be fixed and will be part of the next release.

@saghul I am using the latest code from the v1.x branch. I also tried the [1.4.2 release on libuv.org](http://libuv.org/dist/v1.4.2/). I have also tried with and without running vcbuild.bat.
- Full verbose build output from latest code from v1.x branch: http://pastebin.com/AV8ewBBm
- Full verbose build output from 1.4.2 stable release: http://pastebin.com/s9bqkA50
  - _1.4.2 release has less errors when building but could be beside the point_

@MadLittleMods at the moment there have been [30 commits since 1.4.2 was released](https://github.com/libuv/libuv/compare/v1.4.2...v1.x). I believe @saghul is suggesting you use git or a GitHub generated snapshot such as https://github.com/libuv/libuv/archive/v1.x.zip to get the latest unreleased version.

@rmg I tried that and this is what I mean by "Full verbose build output from latest code from v1.x branch". 

I also just tried the release you linked and got a bunch of errors as well: http://pastebin.com/cVr6jcjC

Sorry, misread your comment.

Are you able to build the sample app? https://github.com/libuv/libuv/tree/v1.x/samples/socks5-proxy

@rmg The socks5-proxy sample produces a lot of errors when trying to build with node-gyp: http://pastebin.com/A2Lp2BnS

Maybe I have to use vcbuild.bat or gyp_uv.py in some way with the gyp build?

If you build a node addon, the version of libuv that ships with that particular version of node is automatically included. However you're trying to link in _another_ version of libuv, so the function and type definitions that you're trying to get from `uv.h` conflict with those that are automatically included.

In other words, don't include libuv as part of your node addon. Just include <node.h> and you'll be able to use the libuv functions that you.

My guess is that the socks5 example may be a little outdated and needs updating to match the latest libuv api.

@MadLittleMods 

1) Did you try [gypjs](https://www.npmjs.com/package/gypjs)

2) In the log files you posted, see the following line:

```
 C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 12.0\VC\bin\x86_amd64\CL.exe /c /I"C:\Users\madli_000\.node-gyp\0.12.1\src" /I"C:\Users\madli
  _000\.node-gyp\0.12.1\deps\uv\include" /I"C:\Users\madli_000\.node-gyp\0.12.1\deps\v8\include" /I..\..\uv\include /I..\..\uv\src /Zi /nologo
   /W3 /WX- /Ox /Ob2 /Oi /Ot /Oy /GL /D WIN32 /D _CRT_SECURE_NO_DEPRECATE /D _CRT_NONSTDC_NO_DEPRECATE /D BUILDING_V8_SHARED=1 /D BUILDING_UV_
  SHARED=1 /D _WIN32_WINNT=0x0600 /D _GNU_SOURCE /GF /Gm- /MT /GS /Gy /fp:precise /Zc:wchar_t /Zc:forScope /GR- /Fo"Release\obj\libuv\\" /Fd"R
  elease\obj\libuv\vc120.pdb" /Gd /TC /wd4351 /wd4355 /wd4800 /wd4251 /errorReport:queue /MP ..\..\uv\src\win\getaddrinfo.c ..\..\uv\src\win\tty.c
```

As you can see, the include directories as specified on the command line are:
- `/I"C:\Users\madli
  _000\.node-gyp\0.12.1\deps\uv\include"`
- `/I..\..\uv\include`

In other words, the include directory for libuv as bundled with node 0.12 is added _before_ the include directory of your own libuv checkout. That means that when you're compiling libuv itself it'll still pick up the wrong `uv.h` file.

I don't know how to fix that. My suggestion would be to try gypjs and if that doesn't work just use gyp proper.
